title: Quiz 10: Zoonotic Diseases & Prevention
description: Final assessment on infections transmitted from animals to humans, covering Anthrax, Rabies, and Brucellosis.

questions.question: What is the term for diseases transmitted between infected vertebrate animals and humans?
questions.explanation: Zoonotic diseases (zoonoses) originate in animals but can infect humans (e.g., Rabies, Anthrax).

questions.question: What is the clinical name for the painless cutaneous anthrax lesion characterized by a black necrotic centre?
questions.explanation: A malignant pustule is the hallmark sign of cutaneous (skin) anthrax.
questions.hint: Check the description of the anthrax skin wound.

questions.question: Which forms of Anthrax are particularly dangerous to humans, carrying high mortality rates? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: While cutaneous anthrax has low mortality, respiratory and digestive forms are severe and often fatal.
questions.hint: Think of internal vs. external entry.

questions.question: What is the case fatality rate of Rabies once clinical signs and symptoms (like hydrophobia) appear?
questions.explanation: Rabies is virtually 100% fatal once clinical symptoms develop. Post-exposure prophylaxis is the only way to save a victim.
questions.hint: It is one of the deadliest known viruses.

questions.question: Why does a patient with 'Furious' Rabies develop intense Hydrophobia (fear of water)?

options.text: Water makes the virus multiply faster
The patient is allergic to water
Swallowing causes intense pain due to pharyngeal spasms

questions.explanation: The fear of water is actually a fear of the excruciating pain caused by attempts to swallow.
questions.hint: Think of muscle spasms in the throat.

questions.question: Arrange the immediate first-aid steps after a suspected rabid animal bite in order of priority:

items.text: Flush wound with soap and plenty of running water for 15 mins

questions.explanation: Immediate flushing is critical to remove the virus before it enters nerve tissue.
questions.hint: The first step is the most life-saving.

questions.question: Brucellosis is an occupational hazard for farmers, abattoir workers, and veterinarians.
questions.explanation: These workers are frequently exposed to infected animal blood, urine, or tissues.

questions.question: Which of the following is the primary route of Brucellosis transmission to the general public?

options.text: Ingestion of unpasteurised milk or milk products

questions.explanation: Most community cases of Brucellosis come from drinking raw milk from infected cattle, goats, or camels.

questions.question: Brucellosis is often characterized by a long-term, 'wavy' fever pattern known as ___BLANK___ fever, and the antibiotic combination of ___BLANK___ and Rifampicin is usually used for 6 weeks.
questions.explanation: Undulant fever is the hallmark; Doxycycline/Rifampicin is the standard treatment.
questions.hint: Check the fever name and the 'D' antibiotic.

questions.explanation: Understanding the reservoir is key to prevention and control strategies.
